title: Why is communism called a failed ideology? - Quora

response.answer_text: Marxism is a failed ideology, but Communism isn’t. Before Marx gave it a Scientific Marxist name, Communism had been known for millennia under several other names. Also, it will stay with humanity long after the last mortal able to recognize Marx without googling the man. Primitive communism Karl Marx himself pointed at it in his description of prehistoric societies. He called them Urkommunismus, because they knew no private property (only individual one) and lived by the principle “From each according to his abilities, to each according to his needs”. God’s will Monotheistic religions have operated inside a very strong Communist paradigm. The world where private property exists is viewed by them as sinful, inferior, and mortal. The Great Beyond, commonly knows as paradise, being the true destination of virtuous souls, knows no private property. Christian monastic societies have been practicing Communism for centuries. They inspired secular Socialists who ultimately gave birth to the Scientific Communist of Karl Marx. "All who believed were together and had all things in common; they would sell their possessions and goods and distribute the proceeds to all, as any had need." ~ Acts 2:44-45. "Now the whole group of those who believed were of one heart and soul, and no one claimed private ownership of any possessions, but everything they owned was held in common. ... There was not a needy person among them, for as many as owned lands or houses sold them and brought the proceeds of what was sold. They laid it at the apostles' feet, and it was distributed to each as any had need." ~ Acts 4:32-35. Us against them The future of Communism, whatever name it takes, is also bright. The way the world works will forever recreate inequality. Some people always will have access to more goods, better experiences, prettier girls, sandier beaches and more fulfilling lives. A grand majority of us will forever view this as bloody injustice and try to find a way to redress the balance. While simple robbing and theft as a means of redistribution and social justice always stays in the realm of the dumb and lazy, the majority will forever prefer redistributing wealth by the power of collective will. Everyone seems to agree on the definition that “rich” are those on the higher rungs—and they better share, or else. Cue in the idea of State-enforced legislation of collective ownership. Et voilá! In times of trouble, Communism is much closer than it appears.  Below, a poster from the early days of Soviet rule in honor of May Day. A giant worker and his son use the celebratory occasion for stomping out parasites, leeches and exploiters. The worker is wearing the striped t-shirt of a military sailor, and his ferocious face suggests he’s very serious about the stomping business. Soviet Communism ultimately collapsed and deeply compromised the brand name of the ideology. However, new slogans embraced nowadays by Western lower classes like “Drain the swamp”, “Take back control” and suchlike, indicate that the thirst for social justice, anti-exploitation and fair redistribution of wealth is immortal. All Communism really needs now is the passage of time. When new generations take the scene and historic memory fades, Communism will just re-brand itself and make a new claim for fame.

Communism is a direct descendant of Marxism. Marxism is, in fact, a failed ideology because its predicted mechanism of action doesn’t work (or so far hasn’t worked). Saying communism works is similar to saying the rhythm method is effective at birth control—looks good in theory with many flaws in practice. Marxism predicted ever-worsening conditions of the lower class and increasing misery in capitalism. In fact, the opposite has happened. No one can doubt there have been abuses by ‘Capitalists.’ Sweatshops, cartels, monopolies (especially in the early days of capitalism) come to mind. In that environment, it was very easy to see how the rich and powerful — like the Vanderbilts and Rockefellers — would continue to get more and more powerful and ultimately crush the workers who would have no power. Reality, of course, is a very different story. The reasoning is quite subtle. MARX’S ECONOMIC IDEOLOGY (in a tiny, condensed nutshell) Marx makes a basic point in Das Kapital that the ‘value’ of a product is directly proportional to the amount of labor that goes into it. In a ‘totally free’ market, competition ‘naturally’ settles prices to the cost of labor. Capitalism still provides profits, however, because the people who ‘own’ the means of production (factories, railroads, etc.) have all of the leverage. Laborers don’t own capital so as a result, they are ‘forced’ to sell their labor to ‘Capitalists’, and they compete until their wage is just enough to sustain them on a daily basis. Why don’t laborers have capital? Because any time they buy capital, ‘bigger’ capitalists buy better machines that make their cost of production much cheaper and drive the smaller capitalists out of business. This spiral continues with bigger and bigger capitalists, more and more people selling their labor and competing for smaller and smaller profits. The resulting competition for labor causes laborers to work extra hours, which is the source of the profits. However, the ‘capital’ itself is only worth the ‘labor’ put into it, so really, the capitalist is working on borrowed time. Competition forces the race to the bottom—increased capital investment, longer working hours, bigger companies with smaller profits, smaller companies going out of business, and less jobs. As wealth concentrates, the ‘labor’ class gets bigger and bigger and more and more miserable until they overthrow the capitalists and install a ‘rule of the working class’ SO WHAT HAPPENED?  Marx is writing right at the first part of the inflection of the curve. His prediction is that capitalists would accumulate all of the means of production and the workers would overthrow the capitalist overlords. That emphatically hasn’t happened, and thank goodness. You can see the difference between ‘Communist’ countries and capitalist for what happens to their average citizen:  To give Marx credit, the ‘Working Class’ did in fact overthrow the capitalists in many societies, such as Russia and China. But those societies still are a far cry from the ‘mass of workers’ as the societies were primarily farming societies. In capitalist societies, the verdict is clear. Despite huge disparities in income, the average person living in a capitalist society is MUCH better off than they were 50 years ago, without exception. WHAT DID MARX FAIL TO SEE? With a relatively inflexible view of the world, I believe Marx has failed on 1 major account: Not realizing the power of government to ‘check’ capitalismNo ‘purely’ capitalistic society exists anymore. We have rules and regulations preventing monopolies. Governments clumsily come in and establish ‘rules for operating’ that companies must follow, including: Workers boards in GermanyMinimum wages across the worldSubsidies and taxes to prevent and correct externalitiesOutright legislation making certain practices illegalConfiscatory taxes (91% nominally on income at some points in the United States) have also helped ensure wealth is redistributed. While capitalism organizes economic activity, it doesn’t organize ALL activity. COMMUNISM WILL NEVER RETURN Marx fundamentally saw capitalism as an unstoppable force that would ultimately consume itself. That didn’t (and so far hasn’t) happened. More importantly, he misunderstood the nature of a proletarian government. A ‘workers party’ does not speak for everyone. Just looking at how Communist Societies (even today) repress dissent provides a much darker picture of subjugating humans to rule. Doubtless there are benefits to strong centralized rule in the name of the people. Check out China’s infrastructure (vs. India’s, for example, or even the US’). There is value to strong centralized authority with the ‘workers’ at the center. However, as an economic ideology opposed to Capitalism, with the technology of the time and even today’s technology, his ideology did not and cannot succeed.
